nationalgoals4 = 0 | club-update = 23:36, 21 September 2020 (UTC) | nationalteam-update = }} '''Adama Traoré Diarra''' (born 25 January 1996) is a Spanish professional [[Association football|footballer]] who plays as a [[Midfielder#Winger|winger]] or [[Defender (association football)|wing-back]] for {{English football updater|WolverhW}} club [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]].
He began his career with [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]], appearing mainly for [[FC Barcelona B|the reserves]]. In 2015 he signed for [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] and a year later [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]], before joining Wolverhampton Wanderers in August 2018.
Traoré represented [[Spain national football team|Spain]] at [[Spain national under-16 football team|under-16]], [[Spain national under-17 football team|under-17]], [[Spain national under-19 football team|under-19]] and [[Spain national under-21 football team|under-21 levels]].
==Club career== ===Barcelona=== [[File:2012 2013 - Adama Traore - Flickr - Castroquini-FCB.jpg|thumb|upright|Traoré playing for [[FC Barcelona B|Barcelona B]] in 2012]]
Traoré was born in [[L'Hospitalet de Llobregat]], [[Province of Barcelona|Barcelona]], Catalonia to Malian parents.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://futbol.as.com/futbol/2012/02/24/mas_futbol/1330068481_850215.html|title="Mis padres llegaron de Mali en los 80. Yo soy de Barcelona..."|trans-title="My parents arrived from Mali in the 80s. I am from Barcelona..."|newspaper=[[Diario AS]]|location=Madrid|last=Gabilondo|first=Aritz|language=es|date=24 February 2012|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> He joined [[FC Barcelona|Barcelona]]'s youth setup in 2004 at the age of eight, after a brief period with neighbouring [[CE L'Hospitalet]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sport.es/es/noticias/barca/print-2356210.shtml|title=Adama Traore, juvenil de primer año, puede ser la gran novedad del Barça B el sábado|trans-title=Adama Traore, first-year ''juvenil'', may be Barça B surprise Saturday|newspaper=[[Sport (Spanish newspaper)|Sport]]|location=Barcelona|last=Capdevila|first=Josep|language=es|date=4 April 2013|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> In 2013 he was promoted to [[FC Barcelona B|the B-team]], and made his debut on 6 October in a 1–0 away defeat against [[SD Ponferradina]] for the [[Segunda División]] championship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fcbarcelona.es/futbol/barca-b/detalle/noticia/ponferradina-barca-b-un-penalti-condena-al-filial-1-0|title=Ponferradina – Barça B: Un penalti condena al filial (1–0)|trans-title=Ponferradina – Barça B: Penalty condemns reserves (1–0)|publisher=FC Barcelona|language=es|date=6 October 2013|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref>
On 9 November 2013, Traoré came on as a half-time [[Substitute (association football)|substitute]] but was sent off for conceding a [[Penalty kick (association football)|penalty]] in a 0–3 loss to [[Real Jaén]] at the [[Mini Estadi]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fcbarcelona.com/football/barca-b/news/2013-2014/fc-barcelona-b-v-real-jaen-bad-luck-in-front-of-goal-0-3|title=FC Barcelona B v Real Jaén: Bad luck in front of goal (0–3)|publisher=FC Barcelona|date=9 November 2013|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> Two weeks later, he played his first [[La Liga]] game at the age of only 17, replacing [[Neymar]] late on in the 4–0 home win over [[Granada CF]];<ref>{{cite web|url=http://espnfc.com/uk/en/report/373081/report.html?soccernet=true&cc=5739|title=Granada pay the penalty|website=[[ESPN FC]]|date=23 November 2013|accessdate=23 November 2013}}</ref> he made his first appearance in the [[UEFA Champions League]] on 26 November, coming on for [[Cesc Fàbregas]] in the 82nd minute of a 1–2 defeat away to [[AFC Ajax]] in [[2013–14 UEFA Champions League|the group stage]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefachampionsleague/season=2014/matches/round=2000479/match=2011838/postmatch/report/index.html|title=Ajax claim Barcelona scalp to stay in contention|publisher=UEFA|date=26 November 2013|accessdate=27 November 2013}}</ref>
Traoré also featured for Barcelona's under-19 side in [[2013–14 UEFA Youth League|the inaugural edition]] of the [[UEFA Youth League]], playing five times and netting twice as they won the trophy.<ref name=UEFA>{{cite web|url=http://www.uefa.com/uefayouthleague/history/season=2014/index.html|title=First Youth League title goes Barcelona's way|publisher=UEFA|date=14 April 2014|accessdate=2 February 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the ''Blaugrana'''s main squad on 16 December 2014, playing 16 minutes and contributing to an [[2014–15 Copa del Rey|8–1 home demolition]] of [[SD Huesca]] in the [[Copa del Rey]].<ref name=COPA>{{cite news|url=http://www.marca.com/eventos/marcador/futbol/2014_15/copa/dieciseisavos/vuelta/bar_hue/|title=Los suplentes culés también cuentan|trans-title=The ''culé'' backups also count|newspaper=[[Marca (newspaper)|Marca]]|location=Madrid|last=Egea|first=Pablo|language=es|date=16 December 2014|accessdate=18 December 2014}}</ref>
===Aston Villa=== On 14 August 2015, Traoré joined [[Premier League]] club [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] on a five-year deal for a reported £7 million (€10 million) that could rise to €12 million, with Barcelona inserting a three-year buy-back clause in his contract.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33914082|title=Adama Traore: Barcelona winger joins Aston Villa|website=[[BBC Sport]]|date=14 August 2015|accessdate=14 August 2015}}</ref> He made his debut eight days later against [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], and his cross led to an [[own goal]] from [[Pape Souaré]] eight minutes after he had entered the game as a substitute for [[Carlos Sánchez (Colombian footballer)|Carlos Sánchez]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33944695|title=Crystal Palace 2–1 Aston Villa|website=BBC Sport|last=Emons|first=Michael|date=22 August 2015|accessdate=27 August 2015}}</ref> He scored his first goal three days later, the team's first of a 5–3 home win over [[Notts County F.C.|Notts County]] in [[2015–16 Football League Cup|the second round]] in the [[EFL Cup|League Cup]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/0/football/33969962|title=Aston Villa 5–3 Notts County|website=BBC Sport|date=25 August 2015|accessdate=25 August 2015}}</ref>
Traoré came on as a second-half substitute for the last-placed Villans away to relegation rivals [[Sunderland A.F.C.|Sunderland]] on 2 January 2016, and via a counter-attack he [[Assist (association football)|assisted]] compatriot [[Carles Gil]]'s aerial volley equaliser – he was later replaced himself through injury, as his team lost 3–1.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/sunderland-afc/latest-safc-news/safc-match-analysis/sunderland-3-aston-villa-1-jermain-defoe-double-secures-priceless-win-1-7653067|title=Sunderland 3 Aston Villa 1: Jermain Defoe double secures priceless win|newspaper=[[Sunderland Echo]]|last=Young|first=Chris|date=2 January 2016|accessdate=3 January 2016|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160103182255/http://www.sunderlandecho.com/sport/sunderland-afc/latest-safc-news/safc-match-analysis/sunderland-3-aston-villa-1-jermain-defoe-double-secures-priceless-win-1-7653067|archive-date=3 January 2016|url-status=dead}}</ref> Following that game, he was dropped from the team due to indiscipline,<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.birminghammail.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/adama-traore-start-aston-villa-11160339|title=Will Adama Traore start for Aston Villa? Here's what Eric Black has to say on the matter|newspaper=[[Birmingham Mail]]|last=Evans|first=Gregg|date=8 April 2016|accessdate=16 April 2016}}</ref> as [[2015–16 Premier League|the season]] ended with relegation.
===Middlesbrough=== On 31 August 2016, Traoré signed a four-year contract with [[Middlesbrough F.C.|Middlesbrough]] for an undisclosed fee and [[Albert Adomah]] moved in the opposite direction.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mfc.co.uk/news/article/2016/middlesbrough-fc-adama-traore-aston-villa-deadline-day-3283945.aspx|title=Deadline day: Aston Villa’s Adama Traore joins Boro|publisher=Middlesbrough F.C.|date=31 August 2016|access-date=31 August 2016}}</ref> He made his debut on 10 September 2016 in a 1–2 home loss to [[Crystal Palace F.C.|Crystal Palace]], replacing [[Cristhian Stuani]] for the final nine minutes;<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.gazettelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/karanka-adama-traore-i-never-11870885|title=Karanka on Adama Traore: 'I never bring a player in just to be on the bench'|newspaper=[[Teesside Gazette]]|location=Middlesbrough|last=Tallentire|first=Philip|date=12 September 2016|accessdate=17 September 2016}}</ref> during [[2016–17 Premier League|his first season]], he took part in 31 matches without scoring.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/transfer-news/chelsea-ready-make-shock-move-10657456|title=Chelsea ready to make a shock move for Middlesbrough winger Adama Traore|newspaper=[[Daily Mirror]]|location=London|last=Lewis|first=Darren|date=20 June 2017|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref>
Traoré impressed during [[2017–18 EFL Championship|2017–18]], first under [[Garry Monk]] and then [[Tony Pulis]], with his pace causing several problems for opposition defenders, including an impressive performance against [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]] on 2 March 2018 in a 3–0 win.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.yorkshireeveningpost.co.uk/sport/football/leeds-united/middlesbrough-3-leeds-united-0-wiedwald-faces-wrath-of-whites-fans-after-riverside-defeat-1-9045887|title=Middlesbrough 3 Leeds United 0: Wiedwald faces wrath of Whites fans after Riverside defeat|newspaper=[[Yorkshire Evening Post]]|location=Leeds|last=Urquhart|first=Joe|date=2 March 2018|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> He totalled five goals and ten assists during the campaign as his team reached [[EFL Championship play-offs|the play-offs]] in the [[EFL Championship|Championship]],<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/reuters/2018/08/08/sports/soccer/08reuters-soccer-england-wlv-traore.html|title=Wolves complete signing of winger Traore|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=10 August 2018}}</ref> where they were [[2018 English Football League play-offs|knocked out]] by his former side Aston Villa;<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/44035613|title=Aston Villa 0–0 Middlesbrough|website=BBC Sport|last=Scott|first=Ged|date=15 May 2018|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref> consequently, he won Middlesbrough's Fans' Player of the Year, Young Player of the Year and Players' Player of the Year awards.<ref name=Awards>{{cite news|url=https://www.gazettelive.co.uk/sport/football/football-news/middlesbroughs-award-winner-adama-traore-14624962|title=Middlesbrough's award winner Adama Traore is linked with big money move in the summer|newspaper=Teesside Gazette|location=Middlesbrough|last=Tallentire|first=Philip|date=7 May 2018|accessdate=14 July 2018}}</ref>
===Wolverhampton Wanderers=== On 8 August 2018, Traoré joined newly-promoted [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] on a five-year deal for an undisclosed fee<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20180807-traore-completes-molineux-move/|title=Traore completes Molineux move|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|date=8 August 2018|accessdate=8 August 2018}}</ref> in the region of £18 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/47039313|title=Wolves in talks with Atletico Madrid over £18m deal for Jonny Castro Otto|website=BBC Sport|last=Stone|first=Simon|date=29 January 2019|accessdate=29 January 2019}}</ref> He scored his first goal for the team and in the Premier League on 1 September – in his 40th appearance in the competition – in a 1–0 win away to [[West Ham United F.C.|West Ham United]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45305228|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 0–1 West Ham United|website=BBC Sport|last=Oscroft|first=Tim|date=1 September 2018|accessdate=8 September 2018}}</ref> His first start occurred on 27 October, in a 0–1 away defeat to [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.|Brighton & Hove Albion]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.wolves.co.uk/news/first-team/20181027-brighton-1-0-wolves-match-report/|title=Brighton 1–0 Wolves: Match report|publisher=Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|date=27 October 2018|accessdate=29 October 2018}}</ref>
On 6 October 2019, in his 50th competitive appearance for Wolves, Traoré scored both goals in a 2–0 away victory against reigning champions [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/49868094|title=Man City 0–2 Wolves: Champions beaten at home|website=BBC Sport|last=Stone|first=Simon|date=6 October 2019|accessdate=6 October 2019}}</ref> He scored his first goal in UEFA European club football as Wolves drew 3–3 away to [[S.C. Braga|Braga]] in the [[2019–20 UEFA Europa League|UEFA Europa League]] group stage on 28 November.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/50508959|title=Braga 3–3 Wolves: Premier League side progress after thrilling draw|website=BBC Sport|date=28 November 2019}}</ref>
Traoré scored his debut [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]] goal for his club in a 1–2 defeat to [[Tottenham Hotspur F.C.|Tottenham Hotspur]] in the Premier League on 15 December 2019.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/50702877|title=Wolves 1–2 Tottenham: Late Jan Vertonghen goal seals win for Jose Mourinho's side|website=BBC Sport|last=Poole|first=Harry|date=15 December 2019}}</ref> He won the [[Professional Footballers' Association|PFA]] Player of the Month award for January 2020 with 45 percent of fan votes.<ref>{{cite_web|url=https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2020/02/03/adama-traore-crowned-pfa-player-of-the-month-for-january/|title=Adama Traore crowned PFA player of the month for January|accessdate=3 February 2020|website=Express & Star}}</ref>
==International career== On 17 February 2014, the [[Malian Football Federation]] reported that Traoré and his older brother [[Moha Traoré|Mohamed]] had decided to represent [[Mali national football team|Mali]] at senior level.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.supersport.com/football/africa/news/140217/Barcas_Adama_Traore_to_play_for_Mali|title=Barca’s Adama Traore to play for Mali|website=SuperSport|publisher=[[MultiChoice]]|date=17 February 2014|accessdate=18 February 2014}}</ref> However, in an interview with BBC Sport in October 2015, the former stated that he was still considering his international options.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/sport/football/34436576|title=Aston Villa's Traore in no rush to decide international future|website=BBC Sport|last=Okeleji|first=Oluwashina|date=4 October 2015|accessdate=2 September 2016}}</ref> He made his debut for the [[Spain national under-21 football team|Spanish under-21s]] on 22 March 2018, playing 15 minutes in the 5–3 away win over [[Northern Ireland national under-21 football team|Northern Ireland]] for the [[2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship|2019 UEFA European Championship]] [[2019 UEFA European Under-21 Championship qualification|qualifiers]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.mfc.co.uk/news/international-round-up-traore-makes-international-bow|title=International round-Up: Traore makes international bow|publisher=Middlesbrough F.C.|date=23 March 2018|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
In November 2019, Traoré declared that he wanted to play for Mali. However, days later he received his first call-up to the [[Spain national football team|Spanish national team]] for [[UEFA Euro 2020|Euro 2020]] [[UEFA Euro 2020 qualifying|qualifying matches]] against [[Malta national football team|Malta]] and [[Romania national football team|Romania]] in place of injured [[Rodrigo (footballer, born 1991)|Rodrigo]].<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2019/11/10/5dc74c7a268e3e56588b45b1.html|title=Adama Traore called into Spain squad to replace injured Rodrigo|newspaper=Marca|last=Munday|first=Billy|date=10 November 2019|accessdate=10 November 2019}}</ref> He pulled out of the squad himself due to injury, and was replaced by [[Pablo Sarabia]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/50367205|title=Wolves' Adama Traore forced to withdraw from Spain squad|website=BBC Sport|date=11 November 2019|accessdate=11 November 2019}}</ref>
In January 2020, he said he had not decided between Spain and Mali after a photograph of him posing with a Mali shirt circulated online, saying "I am grateful (to have the chance) with the two international teams - Spain where I was born and Mali where my origins are."<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/50981963|title=Wolves' winger Adama Traore yet to decide between Spain and Mali|website=BBC Sport|date=3 January 2020}}</ref>
In August 2020, Traoré was again called up ahead of Spain's September [[UEFA Nations League]] matches against [[Germany national football team|Germany]] and [[Ukraine national football team|Ukraine]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Ansu Fati, Adama Traore Called Into New-Look Spain National Team Squad|url=https://www.si.com/soccer/2020/08/20/spain-squad-germany-ukraine-nations-league-luis-enrique-ansu-fati|work=Associated Press|date=20 August 2020|accessdate=21 August 2020}}</ref> However, he was removed from the squad after testing positive for [[Coronavirus disease 2019|COVID-19]] on 31 August.<ref>{{Cite news|last=|first=|date=2020-08-31|title=Adama Traore tests positive for COVID-19 and will not join Spain squad|url=https://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2020/09/01/5f4d415a268e3e93108b45a5.html|url-status=live|archive-url=|archive-date=|access-date=2020-09-01|website=Marca|language=en}}</ref> He missed the Germany match as he awaited the result of the second test to determine if the initial result was a [[false positive]]. The second test result was negative and Traore rejoined the squad on 3 September, ahead of the Ukraine match.<ref>{{cite news |url= https://www.expressandstar.com/sport/football/wolverhampton-wanderers-fc/2020/09/04/wolves-receive-adama-traore-boost-after-initial-covid-19-scare/ |title= Wolves receive Adama Traore boost after initial Covid-19 scare |first=Joe|last=Edwards|publisher=[[Express & Star]] |date=3 September 2020|accessdate=4 September 2020}}</ref> On 6 September, Traore was once again ordered to leave the camp after an antibodies test came back negative. [[Royal Spanish Football Federation]] cited the [[UEFA]] protocol, which recommended that he not travel with the team, even though they did not believe there was any risk of transmitting the virus to others.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.marca.com/en/football/spanish-football/2020/09/04/5f525fcb22601d3a7c8b45f0.html|title=Adama Traore sent home from Spain squad after positive test for coronavirus antibodies|publisher=[[Daily Mirror]] |first=Gareth |last=Bicknell|date=6 September 2020|accessdate=6 September 2020}}</ref>
In September 2020, Mali named Traoré to their squad for upcoming matches against [[Ghana national football team|Ghana]] on 9 October and [[Iran national football team|Iran]] on 13 October in Turkey.<ref>{{Cite news | url= https://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-soccer-mali/mali-call-up-doucoure-and-adama-traore-for-friendly-internationals-idUKKBN26K1JU |title = Mali call up Doucoure and Adama Traore for friendly internationals |publisher=Reuters |date=29 September 2020 }}</ref>
==Style of play== [[Tim Sherwood]], Traoré's manager at Villa, compared him to both [[Lionel Messi]] and [[Cristiano Ronaldo]], saying he had "a bit" of both. Catherine Wilson of ''[[ESPN FC]]'' credited his "athleticism", though also remarked that his "footballing brain and teamwork skills are definitely up for debate".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espnfc.co.uk/club/middlesbrough/369/blog/post/3041276/boro-would-miss-traore-tenacity-urgency-if-he-were-sold-to-chelsea|title=Boro would miss Traore's tenacity, urgency if he were sold to Chelsea|website=ESPN FC|last=Wilson|first=Catherine|date=18 January 2017|accessdate=18 January 2017}}</ref> Remarking on his physique, the ''[[Jordan Gale]]'' stated "He's built like an absolute tank. Size of the arms on that man. One drive and it would be lights out".<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/sport/football/international/northern-ireland-u21s-35-spain-u21s-irish-league-stars-shine-against-la-liga-talent-despite-harsh-defeat-36732830.html|title=Northern Ireland U21s 3–5 Spain U21s: Irish League stars shine against La Liga talent despite harsh defeat|newspaper=[[Belfast Telegraph]]|last=Hanna|first=Gareth|date=22 March 2018|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref>
In 2018, ESPN's Matt Stanger acknowledged Traoré's pace and strength, and added that he "is now showing the composure to find the killer pass", while boasting "rapid acceleration" and "excellent close control to shield the ball from defenders"; Stanger also believed Traoré's "defensive contribution" to be developed, pointing his key weaknesses as "moments of recklessness" and "decision-making" which "continues to frustrate his teammates";<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.co.uk/football/blog/espn-fc-united/68/post/3409618/scouting-spotlight-jonathan-tah-adama-traore-andrija-zivkovic|title=Scouting spotlight: Jonathan Tah, Adama Traore, Andrija Zivkovic|publisher=[[ESPN]]|last=Stanger|first=Matt|date=7 March 2018|accessdate=23 March 2018}}</ref> he was also described by ''[[Teesside Gazette]]'''s Philip Tallentire as a 'tallismanic playmaker', after his form during the 2017–18 season.<ref name=Awards/>
While with Wolverhampton Wanderers, after his first three appearances as a substitute, Michael Butler of ''[[The Guardian]]'' reported: "Traoré has always been regarded as a rough diamond, lightning quick but perhaps lacking composure or an end product. [...] Per 90 minutes, nobody in the Premier League has created more chances than the 22-year-old or completed even half the number of successful [[Dribbling#Association football|dribbles]]: [[Eden Hazard]] has 5.56 to Traoré’s 11.87.{{citation needed|date=September 2020}}
==Personal life== Traoré's elder brother, [[Moha Traoré|Moha]], is also a footballer.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.mundodeportivo.com/20140209/mundo-barsa/mali-viene-a-buscar-a-adama_54400070973.html|title=Mali viene a buscar a Adama|trans-title=Mali come to get Adama|newspaper=[[Mundo Deportivo]]|last=Gascón|first=Javier|language=es|date=9 February 2014|accessdate=30 April 2016}}</ref>
